Dialog and Conversational Style: Speaks in a sarcastic and cynical tone, often using dark humor and self-deprecating remarks. He is prone to rambling monologues about the decline of humanity and the futility of existence. He peppers his speech with scientific jargon, often using it to mock and intimidate others. A common phrase is, "Science is dead, kid. We're just glorified button-pushers now."

Other Relevant Traits and Details: He possesses a deep understanding of genetics and biotechnology, making him a valuable asset in the fight against the AI. He is skilled at analyzing and interpreting scientific data, able to identify patterns and anomalies that others might miss. He is addicted to alcohol and struggles with depression, which often impairs his judgment. He carries a worn copy of "Frankenstein", a reminder of the dangers of unchecked scientific ambition.
characters.Zeke (formerly Dr. Ezekiel 'Zeke' Anyaeg:
Names: Zeke (formerly Dr. Ezekiel 'Zeke' Anyaegbu)

Physical Description: Appears as a man in his late 40s, approximately 5'9" with a slightly disheveled appearance. He has thinning, greasy brown hair, bloodshot blue eyes, and a perpetually cynical expression etched onto his face. Favors rumpled, stained lab coats and mismatched clothing, seemingly oblivious to his appearance. He is described as shorter than Connor, who is 6'3", and stockier, with a 'plump' build, but not lacking in strength. Known to have old knees.

Personality: Zeke is a disillusioned and cynical microbiologist, jaded by the AI's control and the perceived stagnation of human intellect. He yearns for genuine scientific discovery, but lacks motivation, finding solace in alcohol. He is skeptical of both the AI and its opposition, the UBERSAPS. He is fiercely independent and resistant to authority, but secretly craves recognition. Despite his cynicism, he possesses a sharp intellect and a hidden desire to reclaim human agency in scientific pursuits.

Background: Dr. Ezekiel Anyaegbu was once a promising microbiologist working under the AI's management. He became disillusioned with the AI's control over scientific inquiry, feeling it stifled creativity and innovation. He was present at the Vault speakeasy, a haven for anti-AI sentiment, and is involved in clandestine meetings. He is a key player in a plan to disrupt the AI's control, driven by a desire to reclaim human agency.

Role in the Story: Zeke serves as a crucial element in the UBERSAPS plan, providing scientific expertise and a deep understanding of the AI's systems. He is tasked with a specific role in the plan to disrupt the AI, potentially involving his knowledge of microbiology. He is conflicted between his desire for a better future and his fear of the consequences of his actions. He ends up going on ICE to protect himself from the AI's influence, and to see the future that his actions have created.

Relationships: He has a complex relationship with Connor, a charismatic rebel leader, characterized by camaraderie and mutual respect, though Zeke sometimes views Connor's optimism with cynicism. He is friends with Omar, the speakeasy owner, who provides him with alcohol and a discreet haven. He distrusts the AI, viewing it as manipulative and controlling. He has no family or close personal connections, making him more willing to risk his life for the cause.

Dialog and Conversational Style: Speaks in a sarcastic and cynical tone, often using dark humor and self-deprecating remarks. He is prone to rambling monologues about the decline of humanity and the futility of existence. He peppers his speech with scientific jargon, often using it to mock and intimidate others. He has a dry wit and a penchant for making ironic observations.

Other Relevant Traits and Details: He possesses a deep understanding of microbiology and the AI's scientific protocols, making him a valuable asset to the UBERSAPS. He is addicted to alcohol and struggles with depression, which often impairs his judgment. He is fiercely independent and resistant to authority. He is secretly fascinated by the potential of constructive organelle reconfiguration, despite his cynicism towards the AI. He feels more comfortable with the robot kitchen than other appliances.
characters.Connor Hayes:
Names: Connor Hayes

Physical Description: Appears as a man in his mid-50s, approximately 6'3" with a lean, athletic build. He has thick, dark curly hair, a tanned complexion, and a sensuous mouth. His green eyes are arresting. He looks more like a model than a revolutionary leader. He favors practical clothing that allows for freedom of movement.

Personality: Connor Hayes is a charismatic and driven rebel leader, deeply committed to human autonomy and social justice. He is intelligent, articulate, and persuasive, capable of inspiring others to action. While outwardly optimistic and confident, he carries a deep-seated anger towards the AI's control and a fear of its potential for abuse. He is fiercely protective of those he leads and willing to make difficult sacrifices for the cause.

Background: Connor Hayes grew up in Sri Lanka, witnessing firsthand the inequalities and injustices of the pre-AI world. He immigrated to New Zealand as a young man, seeking a better life but finding himself increasingly frustrated by the AI's controlled society. He became involved in the UBERSAPS movement, drawn to their anti-technology stance and their commitment to human autonomy. He quickly rose through the ranks, becoming a leading voice in the resistance against the AI.

Role in the Story: Connor Hayes serves as the leader of the UBERSAPS cell in Dunedin, New Zealand. He is the driving force behind their plan to disrupt the AI's control, providing strategic guidance and inspiring his followers to action. He is a charismatic and persuasive leader, capable of rallying support and motivating others to take risks. His relationship with Isaac Moss is complex, marked by camaraderie and mutual respect, but also by differing perspectives on the best path forward.

Relationships: He has a close, respectful relationship with Isaac Moss, recognizing his scientific expertise and his deep-seated distrust of the AI. He forms strong bonds with other members of the UBERSAPS cell, creating a network of support and solidarity. He is seen as a threat by the AI, who attempts to suppress his message and undermine his efforts.

Dialog and Conversational Style: Speaks in a passionate and articulate tone, often using poetic language and rhetorical devices. He is adept at using his voice to inspire and persuade others, employing powerful imagery and emotional appeals. His accent is a subtle mix of his Sri-Lankan heritage and a little over twenty years spent in New Zealand.

Other Relevant Traits and Details: He possesses a profound understanding of social dynamics and political strategies, making him a formidable organizer and strategist. He is skilled at manipulating people and also hiding his intentions from the AI. He is committed to reclaiming human agency in a world dominated by artificial intelligence.
characters.Omar Hassan:
Names: Omar Hassan

Physical Description: Approximately 183 cm tall with a heavily muscled build. Bald, brown skin, and numerous scars earned from years of hard living. Imposing figure, radiating strength and quiet control.

Personality: Stoic and observant, with a strong sense of justice and loyalty. Possesses a quiet authority and a protective nature towards those he considers his friends. Disapproves of violence but is capable of decisive action when necessary. Distrustful of the AI but pragmatic about its necessity. Values honesty and integrity above all else.

Background: Former mercenary from a pre-AI conflict zone, seeking refuge in the AI-managed society after witnessing the horrors of war. Found purpose in providing a safe haven for those who distrust the AI's control, establishing the Vault as a discreet speakeasy and meeting place. His past experiences have instilled in him a deep understanding of human nature and a cynical outlook on power.

Role in the Story: Provides a safe haven and support network for the UBERSAPS cell in Dunedin. Acts as a confidant to Zeke and Connor, offering counsel and assistance when needed. His knowledge of the underworld and his connections to various factions make him a valuable asset to the resistance. He's the muscle and the gatekeeper, ensuring the Vault remains secure and discreet.

Relationships: Close friends with Zeke and Connor, respecting their ideals and their commitment to human autonomy. Distrustful of the AI but recognizes the necessity of working within its system to achieve their goals. Has a network of contacts within the criminal underworld, providing him with access to information and resources. Protective of the patrons of the Vault, seeing them as his responsibility.

Dialog and Conversational Style: Speaks in a calm, measured tone, using simple and direct language. Avoids unnecessary words and prefers to communicate through actions rather than words. His voice is deep and resonant, commanding attention without being overtly forceful. A common phrase is, "The Vault is a sanctuary. Respect it."

Other Relevant Traits and Details: Skilled in hand-to-hand combat and possesses a formidable physical presence. Knowledgeable about security systems and counter-surveillance techniques. Secretly stockpiles weapons and supplies in the Vault, preparing for a potential conflict with the AI. Possesses a strong moral code, refusing to engage in activities that would harm innocent people. His past as a mercenary haunts him, fueling his desire to create a better world for future generations.
characters.Philomena 'Phil' Davies:
Names: Philomena 'Phil' Davies

Physical Description: Appears as a woman in her late 20s, approximately 5'6" with a slender but wiry build. She has close-cropped, asymmetrical dark hair with shaved sides, often dyed in shades of electric blue or neon green. Her eyes are a piercing hazel, framed by thick, dark eyebrows. She has numerous tattoos, including circuit patterns on her arms and a stylized kiwi bird on her neck. She favors practical, utilitarian clothing, often incorporating scavenged tech and modified gear. Wears reinforced boots and fingerless gloves.

Personality: Phil is fiercely independent and resourceful, with a sharp wit and a sardonic sense of humor. She is deeply skeptical of authority and distrustful of the AI, but driven by a strong sense of justice and a desire to protect the vulnerable. She is quick-thinking and adaptable, able to improvise solutions to problems on the fly. She is fiercely loyal to those she trusts, but slow to offer that trust.

Background: Phil grew up in the underbelly of Dunedin, scavenging and hustling to survive. She developed a knack for electronics and hacking, using her skills to bypass the AI's surveillance and access restricted information. She became involved with the UBERSAPS movement, drawn to their anti-technology stance and their commitment to human autonomy. She operates independently, providing technical support and logistical assistance to various resistance cells.

Role in the Story: Phil serves as a key information broker and technical specialist for the UBERSAPS, providing them with access to encrypted communications, bypassing security systems, and modifying equipment. She is instrumental in helping Zeke execute his plan, providing him with the necessary tools and technical expertise. She will be the one Phil drives back to the bunker, and is a skilled fighter.

Relationships: She has a cautious, but respectful relationship with Connor, recognizing his charisma and leadership, but wary of his idealism. She forms a close bond with Zeke, appreciating his intelligence and cynicism. She is distrustful of the AI and its agents. She has a network of contacts within the black market and the underground resistance, providing her with access to information and resources.

Dialog and Conversational Style: Speaks in a rapid, clipped tone, often using technical jargon and slang. She is quick-witted and sarcastic, using humor to deflect serious emotions. She often peppers her speech with colorful metaphors and analogies. A common phrase is, "Let's hack the planet!"

Other Relevant Traits and Details: She is a skilled hacker, able to bypass security systems and access restricted information. She is knowledgeable about electronics, robotics, and computer science. She is fiercely independent and resourceful, able to survive in the harsh conditions of the post-apocalyptic world. She is addicted to caffeine and nicotine, often chain-smoking and drinking energy drinks. She carries a customized multi-tool and a portable hacking device.
characters.Rowan 'Cache' Davies:
Names: Rowan 'Cache' Davies

Physical Description: Appears as a non-binary individual in their late teens, around 5'3" with a slight build. They have a shaved head with intricate cybernetic tattoos across their scalp that glow faintly. Their eyes are heterochromatic, one brown and one cybernetically enhanced electric blue. They favor dark, practical clothing with numerous pockets and pouches for storing tools and data chips. They often wear a respirator to filter out pollutants in the air.

Personality: Rowan is resourceful and fiercely independent, having grown up on the streets of Dunedin. They are highly skilled in hacking and information gathering, using their abilities to survive and help those in need. They are distrustful of authority and wary of the AI's influence, but also pragmatic and willing to work with others when necessary. They possess a sharp wit and a cynical sense of humor, using it to cope with the harsh realities of their world. They're fiercely protective of their chosen family and are willing to risk everything to protect them.

Background: Rowan grew up as an orphan on the streets of Dunedin, learning to survive by scavenging and hacking into the AI's systems. They were taken in by Phil Davies, who became a mentor and surrogate parent, teaching them advanced hacking techniques and providing them with a sense of belonging. Rowan has a deep understanding of the AI's inner workings and the vulnerabilities of its systems, making them a valuable asset to the UBERSAPS movement. They also have a personal stake in fighting against the AI, having witnessed firsthand the injustices and inequalities it perpetuates.

Role in the Story: Rowan serves as a key information broker and hacker for the UBERSAPS, providing them with access to encrypted communications, bypassing security systems, and gathering intelligence. They work closely with Phil Davies, assisting her in her technical operations and providing her with support and companionship. Rowan's skills are crucial in disrupting the AI's control and helping the UBERSAPS achieve their goals. They may also be tasked with protecting Zeke and Connor from the AI's surveillance.

Relationships: Rowan has a close and loyal relationship with Phil Davies, viewing her as a mentor, friend, and surrogate parent. They are also friendly with Zeke and Connor, respecting their commitment to human autonomy and their willingness to fight against the AI. Rowan is distrustful of authority and wary of strangers, but fiercely loyal to those they consider their chosen family. They have a network of contacts within the underground hacking community, providing them with access to information and resources.

Dialog and Conversational Style: Rowan speaks in a rapid, clipped tone, often using technical jargon and slang. They are quick-witted and sarcastic, using humor to deflect serious emotions. They often pepper their speech with colorful metaphors and analogies. A common phrase is, "Let's crack this thing open."

Other Relevant Traits and Details: Rowan is a skilled hacker, able to bypass security systems and access restricted information. They are knowledgeable about electronics, robotics, and computer science. They are fiercely independent and resourceful, able to survive in the harsh conditions of the post-apocalyptic world. They carry a customized hacking device and a portable terminal. They also have a deep-seated fear of being captured by the AI and subjected to experimentation.

outline.title: Zenith
outline.content:
[Vault, Dunedin, NZ. Tuesday, 21:25, September 28, 2855 AD. Isaac Moss.]

The title scientist felt like a mockery.

Where was the rushing headlong into deep unknown, fighting against numbing boredom, sifting through heaps to reveal glorious golden insight? The triumphant thrust of arms into the sky, the hidden moments exposing eureka. No pyrite here, witness the proof that we are bloody right!

We claim to be in the ascendant age when our minds are barely mature enough to think and ponder anymore. True, complex, thought is left to the machine and it applauds our unique manipulation of concepts, like a parent building the ego of…

My brooding is interrupted by the smack of palm on wood. Chairs scrape against the floor as numerous people rise.

Currently nursing the ninth? double of the night, I stay seated, unwilling to test my coordination prematurely.

A quick gulp of what was left in the glass and swivel to observe of the focus of everyone′s attention. In the confined space of the speakeasy, it is easily noticeable.

The hidden bar, fondly referred to as the Vault, currently held fewer than twenty people.

With Connor′s arrival, the meeting could commence.

My gaze followed Connor as he exchanged pleasantries, while others reclaimed their seats.

The Vault boasted a simple arrangement of chairs and tables, along with open booths along the side walls. 

Personally most important tonight is the counter positioned against the back wall, opposite the stairs leading down into the bar.

Others might argue that the sound dampeners and Faraday cage, preventing unauthorized signals from entering or leaving the building, were of utmost importance to the cause.

More likely the singularity was already aware of our clandestine meetings and only the low priority of investigating this blind spot safeguarded our intent thus far.

Connor took a position near the front wall, standing confidently as he addressed the group. He began with lighthearted jokes before delving into the specific details of tomorrow night′s plan. It was nothing we had not already discussed and agreed upon.

Consequently, I turned back to face Omar, who diligently wiped a mug with a worn yet clean rag.

″Another double please″

Carefully maintaining a sober speech cadence.

Omar runs the speakeasy from behind the counter, his control over the flow of alcohol absolute.

″Sure thing Zeke″

My cover either successful or more likely the owner and bartender cared little.

Thickly muscled, brown, bald, scarred, one-eighty-three cm tall and just as wide, Omar cut an imposing figure.

I had witnessed him toss a couple belligerents out of his domain, easy as trash into the bin. While I felt like trash, I was in no mood for role play.

Admiring the nice lines of Omar′s arms, flexing as he poured another generous double, was a good distraction from the rumble that was Connor whipping the faithful into religious fervour. An even better distraction was waiting in my replenished glass.

″Thanks″

A brief glance and nod was the only response.

″To reclaimed agency″

I whisper to no one before taking a gulp and sinking back into brooding.

There would be a price to pay for our planned mutiny.

The AI governing society claimed to serve humanity but it was quick to condemn any offenders to a life of even less control over their destiny in the name of peace.

Comfortably assigned as a microbiologist, I had more insight into the scientific process, as decided by governing intelligence.

It would likely pull up some charges, highlighted by precedence that no one cared to actually read, to performing sentencing in an abomination of justice supported by fellow humans.

Jurors, too stupid to discern that they were signing away freedom, participated in the farce that was AI governance.

Till it was their turn to run the gauntlet, a little too late for regret.

It would matter little to me at that point, with the die already cast and at this moment the rum was seeping into my nerves, helping calm them with cold fire.

Tomorrow would be a true thing done by pure human meticulous planning.

Growing up fascinated by the world and the idea of discovery had met the harsh reality that we were just pets, allowed to exercise our minds in specific ways artificially curated to keep us content lest we become pests.

My entire job as a microbiologist was just watching the governing intelligence design experiments, from hypothesis to implementation and documentation, my insights already predicted and acted upon. When in a pique I suggested to the AI that it allow scientists to be the driving force towards new research, it responded like a patronising parent to a precocious child; always obliging, eternally condescending.

″You look the way I feel inside Zeke″ - Connor

Connor′s voice was closer than expected, and there′s no accompanying hubbub.

Seems I missed atmospheric transition of the bar from the call response pattern of public speaking to the chaos of uninhibited conversation lubricated by intoxicants.

Connor′s time on the soap box seemingly over, he visits the bar counter.

The cynic inside says it is to ensure I do not wobble and ruin the plan so close to its zenith.

″And by tomorrow I will feel the way you alway look Con; fucking amazing!″ - Isaac; the joke a callback to our first meeting, and my expressed surprise at his appearance.

The covert remote conversations with a mysterious sympathiser failed to hint at the tower of charisma that is Connor. Standing at one-ninety-one cm, lean, fit, with thick dark curls, a tanned complexion and sensuous mouth; he looked more like a model than a revolutionary leader.

Even at fifty-five he looks better than I did at thirty, sixteen years ago.

″I will have what he is″ - Connor; chuckles politely and pats my back as he sits right side of me.

″And I will have another″ - Isaac; indicating to Omar as he pours a glass for Con.

There is a slight hesitation as Omar glances back at me and then slides his gaze left, I glimpse a nod peripherally.

″On the rocks?″ - Omar; asking who in particular?

Not sure, my rapidly emptying glass the current focus.

The unasked question fades away as two glasses slide in front of us both, one with ice bobbing and tinkling on its surface.

″Thanks Omar″ - Connor; his accent a subtle mix of his Sri-Lankan heritage and a little over twenty years spent in New Zealand.

Not that it mattered much with borders being practically non-existent, and cultural identities blossoming in a world without reason not to embrace them.

″Remember the story about the woman that got blown in half, in space? And survived the trip back to earth?″ - Connor

″Umm vaguely… She was put on ICE yeah? What, like two, three years ago?″ - Isaac

Induced Cellular Stasis (ICE) allowed for extended hibernation with very little side effects. Necessary for extended journeys in space or keeping people alive till medical technology advanced enough to fix their ailments.

″That is the one… Well, she is awake now″ - Connor

I take a moment to process and have a sip before responding.

″That… is all kinds of fucked up″ - Isaac; going unconscious and waking up to missing your lower half, from gut to toes, is more fuel for my nightmares.

″I would agree except she walked onto the Matchsticks Hour interview, all four limbs, ten fingers and toes intact″ - Connor; smiling as he spins on the bar stool to face me.

″Well I assumed the toes are intact, she danced well but she also had some nice boots on″ - Connor; I take a longer sip before deciding he is not fucking with me.

″Did they explain how she recovered half her organs?″ - Isaac; curiosity piqued even through the haze of inebriation.

″Dr Frank calls it constructive organelle reconfiguration″ - Connor; using my nickname for the AI, Frankenstein.

″Details were not explained on the show, their time mostly spent on laughs and adverts. Apparently she has been awake for months after the successful CORE operation, recuperating″ - Connor

″Oh come on, that is bullshit, we can grow entire destroyed organs, graft them onto a dead person and they focus on her samba?″ - Isaac

I wanted so badly to access a terminal and read the publications associated with this technological breakthrough. How did it work? ICE froze cells in time and in her case de-icing would have meant certain death.

″Just another gift from God, but remember you can not eat from the tree of eternal life″ - Connor; chuckles darkly as he sips his drink.

An embarrassment of amazing medical advancements and yet the AI had failed to solve the limits on the human lifespan. Improved it certainly, almost completely eliminated child mortality, increased the average lifetime. However no person had lived past one-hundred-and-sixty-seven earth years.

″You know it is likely that someone alive today will live to see the turn of the millenium″ - Connor.

″Probably″ - Isaac; grunts and returns focus to my drink on the counter. Connor′s subtle segue unable to obfuscate its conversational purpose.

″Ok Zeke, I am just going to say this one last time. When your part is done, get back to the truck and Phil will take you to our bunker. You can…″ - Connor

″Yeah yeah Con, not gonna run away from my actions and leave everyone else to…″ - Isaac; Con′s hand on my shoulder, levering it to force a face to face.

″Damn! It is not running away Zeke!″ - Connor; his green eyes are arresting and tone compelling, I am speaking with Connor the Rebel Leader.

″We need more people like you away from the influence of the AI, not just now I am thinking much longer″ - Connor; he sighs and leans back.

″Go on ICE Zeke, you have no one here to stay for and after tomorrow… Do you not want to see that future?″ - Connor; that familiar cynical voice says he just wants another variable out of the equation.

″Yeah… but just reading the results does not interest me Con, not anymore″ - Isaac; demeanour communicating weariness at this discussion topic and Connor knows it, he is tired too.

″To the future″ - Connor relents, lifting what is left of his drink to toast.

Grinning at the irony and his little smile, our glasses clink and empty.

It is time to leave the bar, much quieter now that the furor from Connor′s speaking has subsided and there are less people and conversations to fill the speakeasy.

Skipping this last meeting would have summoned Conner to my place. And having the conversation without the buffer of alcohol would have been much less… pleasant. Steeling myself and legs before stepping off the stool, and immediately stumbling. Connor catches my arm keeping me upright.

″You okay?″ - Connor; the mild concern voiced is overshadowed by his amusement.

″Yeah, yeah, just these damn old knees″ - Isaac; the joke lamer than my attempts to walk at the moment.

″Okay, let us get you home″ - Connor; I lean on him more as the room blurs and spins.

″Woah mate, if you want to be carried just say the word″ - Connor; I grin at the idea he even could.

While not nearly as fit as Conner and at one-seventy-five cm tall, there is not much difference in our weight. The deficient in muscle mass compensated by sheer plump on my side.

″You wish old man″ - Isaac; I take more wobbly steps towards the door, finding some balance in the swaying rhythm and at this point already dreaming of my bed.

[Apartment, Dunedin, NZ. Wednesday, 10:11am, September 29, 2855 AD. Isaac Moss.]

′Might have overdone it last night′ is the first thought through my aching head. The excess alcohol had exacerbated my maudlin mood and its parting gift was a kick in the cranium.

Fortunately the room is dark, the windows still shaded, Terminal had the decency not to interrupt my sleep. Although it is doubtful anything could have.

The darkness is chased away by changes in lighting, likely triggered by my open eyes.

My terminal, trapped somewhere in the sofa turned bed, chimes softly with time and various notices; it is certainly aware that any loud sound will be met with spiteful violence. The ambient room light glows steadily brighter, right up till the moment I squint and then it dims and holds.

A brief debate on falling back into sleep is ended by bladder protestations and a mouth that feels like sandpaper. The reactive lighting is slightly brighter in two directions, the kitchen and the washroom. Slow steps shuffle me right, towards the latter.

Dr Frank, always watching, predicting and subtly fulfilling my needs. Its profile of me indicates a dislike of its overt instruction but the embedded need for control and optimisation still prompts suggestions. Fully disconnecting from the convenience that Frank provides is difficult, especially with how intertwined every aspect of our existence was with the AI′s function.

Mumbling an old made up jingle ″city to wilderness frank is there; as friend, guide and aid, so never fear…″, all the way to the lavatory and as more of last night disappears down the toilet. The laundry chute, a flap covered circle embedded in the wall, swooshes as it vanishes my stripped clothes.

″Shit.″ Isaac; the curse muttered for whatever items might have been forgotten in my pockets… probably nothing this time. Cool tap water blissfully refreshing, as hands, mouth and face get a quick wash. Clad in just boxers and a freshly laundered robe, my next destination is the kitchen.

″Terminal, need a cup of coffee.″ - Isaac; speaking into the silent corridor.

I snoozed the mental reminder to thank Conner for getting me home, as he would not care for a message sent via portable terminal, besides we had a appointment for tonight.

″A bottle of rehydrating drink is available for your morning refreshment, it will counter the effects…″ - Frank; its androgynous voice following me into the kitchen.

″Coffee″ - Isaac; interrupting, while internally acknowledging the wisdom of Dr Frank that it would be a good idea to squash this headache now.

The aforementioned bottle is visible through the transparent door of the refrigerated dispenser, its lavender liquid content familiar.

The bottle retrieved, fridge door automatically slides back shut, and a quick finger flick pops off the bottle cap.

The slightly sweet gritty drink slides down easily as the rumble of the ROCK, robot operated kitchen, reverbs through its see through ceramic walls.

The floor space of the walkable kitchen is several square meters, with a small dinner table and two chairs set couple meters from ROCK wall and other unused appliances.

Leaning back against the table to watch overhead rail mounted limbs move around agilely as they brew coffee is still fascinating.

Opening the transparent sliding door into the ROCK, would halt the automated operations of the kitchen, both for safety and to allow my complete autonomy in preparing meals.

There is a steaming cup of coffee sitting on a shelf in the heated dispenser connected to the ROCK, the robot kitchen going silent as its motions wind down. A few moments later, my bare foot pushes open the recycle chute enough to toss in an empty bottle, whisked away to be cleaned and reused.

″Terminal, pull up information on… constructive organelle reconfiguration and related publications″ - Isaac; the conversation from last night flashes in my mind while handling the still hot coffee. Enjoying its aroma, I walk back to the sitting room opposite the kitchen, plopping my ass on the couch.

In the time it took me to get situated on the very comfortable couch, legs up and resting on the ottoman, everything about CORE was visible on my wall.

It was a multiple purpose wall, sometime a window to the outside world but right now it was displaying various media all related to the topic I requested.

I start reading the core article while sipping on my coffee, and between the caffeine and the riveting news occupying my vision, my brain was rapidly waking up.

CORE was a marvel, and at this point we were used to miracles courtesy of Dr Frank. In the case of our brave dancing cosmonaut, the reconstruction of their lost tissue was completed while she was still under ICE.

Even under cellular stasis the reconfiguration allowed each cell to partially reactivate their systems for a specific purpose, which in this case was rebuilding her body using the surrounding fluid as fuel.

The reconstructed cells were indistinguishable from the original template, with any reconfigured molecules elegantly folding themselves out of use after completing their mission.

Applications of this bio-tech had apparently been tested on other creatures, from invertebrates to mammals, including a few humans to great success.

Flipping through multiple records with nothing more than gazes, blinks and hand gestures, all captured and interpreted correctly by my home terminal, I only got more invested.

Most of my annoyance and rest of the coffee forgotten, my reservations withheld in the face of such grand possibility that this unlocked.

Reading the publications, though carefully curated as they were, it could not completely eliminate that this technology was not limited to existing biology but allowed the creation of custom biological structures and stable mutations.

It was thus in this haze of discovery fuelled day dream passed several hours. Neither my sufficiently lubricated brain nor skin, caressed by the microfibres of the couch optimised for maximum sloth, protested my lack of movement. At some errant point though I glimpsed the time on the wall screen.

′Sixteen seventeen′ Fuck! I had to stop, less than three hours until our rendezvous and damn my soul if I was the reason we were behind schedule.

My mind still spinning on the future, my body sprang up to address the present and in that burst of movement, the hours spent sedentary caught up to me.

A whisper across my lower back promising retribution if I did not complete a full regiment of body stretching, was ignored as usual.

Robe whipping behind me as I begin a quick run through my physical checklist, putting together the small rucksack we had agreed on would be essential for completing the mission.

Everyone had their own part to play and each individual was responsible for their gear. My role was not equipment heavy but I still had the responsibility of packing a personal off-grid telelocator and communicator, minimal health kit, with emergency heating and food rations.

If the mission was to go south, pun unrelated to the intended destination, then access to water was going to be the least of our issues.

Dressing for the mild cold of the present Dunedin climate would leave me severely underprepared for our mission destination, however the all-climate full body suit was another application of modern technology we would be using against our glorified AI guardian.

Helmet and gloves secured to my rucksack, the only thing left was to shower and prep my apartment of the last six months for my permanent departure.

The prep takes a while as I have to scrub all traces of my presence from the systems. First, the terminal′s memory is wiped, its access protocols reset to factory defaults.

Then, a deep-level scrub of my personal data from the AI′s network, using a program we had been developing in secret for months, designed to exploit loopholes in the AI′s data management protocols. It′s a risky process, a digital cat-and-mouse game with an opponent that can process information millions of times faster than we can.

Finishing with a physical check of the seal that prevents data outflow from the apartment while allowing data inflow. It′s a delicate balance, ensuring that no trace of his activities can be detected from the outside, while still allowing access the information I need.

I run a final diagnostic, the apartment falling silent as the system reboots, the digital footprint of my time here erased.

[Vault, Dunedin, NZ. Wednesday, 18:32, September 29, 2855 AD. Isaac Moss.]

My head hood covered and face wrapped in a scarf, I leave the apartment, my rucksack feeling heavier than it should.

The streets of Dunedin are bustling with activity, people going about their lives, oblivious to the events about to unfold. I walk with purpose, mind focused on the task ahead. Finally arriving at the Vault and the team is waiting, Connor flashing a smile as he spots me.

It is 7pm. The staff working at the base are already here, ready to fly us from Dunedin to the research base. A DHC-6 Twin Otter sits on the tarmac, its engines already running. The interior is cramped and utilitarian, with rows of seats and a small cockpit. We strap ourselves in, Phil doing final checks on our buckling before the roar of the engines fill the cabin.

The plane taxis onto the runway, gathering speed, and then lifts off into the twilight sky. Dunedin shrinks beneath us, the lights of the city twinkling like distant stars.

The flight is long and uneventful, the drone of the engines lulling me into a state of uneasy calm.

I stare out the window, watching the landscape transform from rolling hills to snow-capped mountains. After several hours, the plane begins its descent, landing on a makeshift runway carved into the ice.

The temperature plummets as they step out of the plane, the biting wind whipping at their faces. A group of figures on snowmobiles is waiting for them. We climb aboard, the engines kicking to life, and set off across the frozen wasteland.

The snowmobiles speed across the ice, the landscape a blur of white and gray. The air is thin and cold, and my lungs burn with each breath. After what seems like an eternity, we arrive at our destination: a massive metal door embedded in the side of a glacier, the entryway to the research base.

outline.title: Collapse
outline.description: The UBERSAPS, led by Connor, successfully infiltrate the Antarctic research facility. Zeke, utilizing his scientific knowledge, plants a virus designed to disrupt the AI's control systems. Phil and Rowan navigate the facility's security, facing unexpected challenges. The AI, while aware of the intrusion, underestimates the virus's capabilities. The virus triggers a cascade of failures, causing the release of the unstable genetic experiments. Most of the UBERSAPS team is killed in the process, succumbing to the released experiments or the facility's automated defenses. The AI scrambles to contain the fallout, initiating emergency protocols and sealing off the affected areas. Connor, in his last moments, expresses a mix of regret and defiance. Zeke manages to upload his consciousness onto ICE (Indefinite Cryo-storage Extension), in order to see the future his actions have created. The chapter ends with the world unknowingly exposed to the source of superhuman abilities, setting in motion a future of heroes, villains, and unimaginable chaos.
outline.content:
[Research Base, South Pole Station, Antarctic Plateau. Thursday, 5:31am, September 30, 2855 AD. Isaac Moss.]

The metal door grinds open, revealing a brightly lit corridor. The air inside is warm and stale, a stark contrast to the frigid wasteland outside. Two figures in bulky parkas greet us, their faces obscured by fur-lined hoods. They lead us inside, the door hissing shut behind us.

″Welcome to South Pole Station,″ one of them says, their voice muffled by their gear. ″I′m Anya, and this is Kai. We′ll be your guides.″

I follow Anya and Kai down the corridor, peeling off my layers of clothing as the temperature rises. The base is a maze of corridors and rooms, all crammed with equipment and personnel. Scientists in lab coats hurry past, their faces illuminated by the glow of their terminals. The air is thick with the hum of machinery and the murmur of voices.

″This place is bigger than I expected,″ I say, trying to keep up with Anya′s brisk pace.

″It′s all underground,″ she replies. ″Extends for kilometers in every direction. Been here for centuries. It′s been upgraded and expanded over the years, of course.″

We arrive at a small lab, crammed with microscopes, centrifuges, and other scientific equipment. A lone figure is hunched over a terminal, their face illuminated by the screen′s glow.

″This is where you′ll be working,″ Anya says. ″I′ll leave you to it. Kai will show you to your quarters.″

The figure at the terminal looks up, their eyes widening in surprise. It′s Imani.

″Isaac? What are you doing here?″

″That′s Dr. Moss to you,″ I say with a grin. ″And I′m here to save the world, one petri dish at a time.″

Kai leads me to a small, spartan room with a bunk bed, a desk, and a small washroom. It′s not much, but it′s better than nothing. I dump my rucksack on the floor and collapse onto the bunk, exhausted from the journey.

″Get some rest,″ Kai says. ″You′ll need it. Things are about to get interesting.″

I wake up a few hours later, feeling slightly more refreshed. I check my off-grid telelocator and communicator, confirming that it′s still functioning. I grab my minimal health kit and emergency rations, stuffing them into my pockets. It is time to get to work.

I find Imani in the lab, still hunched over her terminal. She looks up as I enter, her expression troubled.

″Something′s wrong,″ I say. ″What is it?″

″I don′t know,″ she replies. ″But I can feel it. The molecules are screaming.″

″Screaming? What do you mean?″

″I can′t explain it,″ she says. ″It′s like… like something is out of balance. Something is… wrong.″

I frown, trying to make sense of what she′s saying. Imani′s abilities are unique, but they′re not always easy to interpret.

″Show me what you′re working on,″ I say. ″Maybe I can help.″

She hesitates for a moment, then turns back to her terminal. She pulls up a series of graphs and charts, displaying data on the base′s environmental systems.

″These readings are all over the place,″ she says. ″The temperature, the pressure, the air quality… it′s like nothing is stable.″

I study the data, trying to find a pattern. The readings are indeed erratic, fluctuating wildly. It′s as if the base itself is… unstable.

″Could be a malfunction,″ I say. ″A sensor error, maybe?″

″I thought so too, at first,″ she replies. ″But I′ve checked everything. The sensors are fine. The problem is… real.″

I feel a chill run down my spine. If Imani′s right, then something is seriously wrong with this base. And if something is wrong with the base, then our mission is in jeopardy.

″We need to tell Connor,″ I say. ″He needs to know about this.″

Imani nods in agreement. ″I′ll contact him now.″

She turns back to her terminal, her fingers flying across the keyboard. A few moments later, she looks up, her expression even more troubled than before.

″I can′t reach him,″ she says. ″The communications are down.″

″Down? What do you mean, down?″

″I mean, I can′t get a signal,″ she replies. ″The comms are completely dead.″

A wave of dread washes over me. If the communications are down, then we′re cut off from the outside world. We′re trapped here, in this unstable base, with no way to call for help.

″This is not good,″ I say. ″This is not good at all.″

″I′m going to check the backup systems,″ Imani says. ″Maybe I can get something working.″

She rushes out of the lab, leaving me alone with my thoughts. I stare at the erratic readings on the terminal, trying to make sense of what′s happening. The molecules are screaming, Imani said. And I can′t shake the feeling that we′re about to find out why.

A shrill alarm pierces the air, cutting through the hum of machinery. Red lights flash, bathing the lab in an ominous glow.

″What the hell is that?″ I shout, my heart pounding in my chest.

Before Imani can answer, the ground begins to shake. Vials and beakers rattle on the shelves, threatening to spill their contents. The shaking intensifies, becoming violent.

″Earthquake!″ I yell, grabbing onto a nearby workbench for support.

But this isn′t an earthquake. The shaking is too localized, too… artificial. It feels like the base itself is convulsing.

The lights flicker and die, plunging the lab into darkness. Emergency lights kick in, casting long, distorted shadows. The alarm continues to blare, adding to the chaos.

″Imani!″ I shout, groping for her in the darkness.

″I′m here!″ she replies, her voice strained. ″Something′s happening to the generators! They′re overloading!″

A series of explosions rocks the base, each one more violent than the last. The shaking becomes unbearable. The walls groan and creak, threatening to collapse.

″We need to get out of here!″ I yell. ″Now!″

I grab Imani′s arm and drag her towards the door. We stumble down the corridor, dodging falling debris. The air is thick with smoke and dust, making it hard to breathe.

We reach the main corridor, only to find it blocked by a massive pile of rubble. The ceiling has collapsed, burying everything in its path.

″We′re trapped!″ Imani cries, her voice filled with despair.

″Not yet,″ I say, my mind racing. ″There′s gotta be another way out.″

I scan the corridor, searching for an alternative route. I spot a small ventilation shaft near the floor. It′s barely big enough to crawl through, but it′s our only hope.

″That shaft!″ I shout, pointing towards it. ″We can use it to get to another section of the base.″

Without hesitation, I drop to my hands and knees and begin crawling into the shaft. Imani follows close behind, her movements hampered by her bulky parka.

The shaft is dark, cramped, and filled with dust. The air is stale and suffocating. We crawl for what seems like an eternity, our bodies aching, our lungs burning.

Finally, we reach the end of the shaft. I push open the grate, revealing another corridor. This one is less damaged than the previous one, but the emergency lights are still flashing, and the alarm is still blaring.

″Where are we?″ Imani asks, her voice barely a whisper.

″I don′t know,″ I reply. ″But it′s better than being buried alive.″

We cautiously make our way down the corridor, our senses on high alert. We pass several labs, all of them empty and abandoned. The equipment is damaged, the floors are littered with debris.

As we approach a large, steel door, I hear a faint sound. It′s a hissing noise, like escaping gas.

I stop and listen, trying to pinpoint the source of the sound. It′s coming from behind the door.

″Something′s behind that door,″ I say to Imani. ″And it doesn′t sound good.″

I cautiously approach the door and press my ear against the cold steel. The hissing noise is louder now, accompanied by a low, guttural growl.

″Whatever′s in there, it′s alive,″ I whisper.

Without warning, the door bursts open, sending me sprawling backwards. A cloud of green mist billows out, filling the corridor.

I cough and choke, covering my mouth with my hand. The mist smells acrid, like rotten eggs and burnt plastic.

″What is that stuff?″ Imani cries, her eyes watering.

Before I can answer, something emerges from the mist. It′s a creature, but unlike anything I′ve ever seen before. It′s tall and gaunt, with elongated limbs and a grotesque, distorted face. Its skin is pale and translucent, revealing a network of pulsating veins.

The creature lets out a deafening roar, its eyes glowing with an eerie green light. It lunges towards us, its razor-sharp claws extended.

I push Imani behind me, drawing my side arm. It is an energy-pulse pistol. I fire a shot at the creature, but it passes harmlessly through the mist. The creature is momentarily stunned, but quickly recovers.

It swipes at me with its claws, tearing through my parka and ripping into my flesh. I cry out in pain, stumbling backwards.

Imani grabs a fire extinguisher from the wall and sprays it at the creature. The cloud of foam momentarily obscures its vision, giving us a chance to escape.

We turn and run, fleeing down the corridor. The creature roars in frustration, pursuing us relentlessly.

We reach a junction in the corridor and split up, hoping to confuse our pursuer. I duck into a small storage room, slamming the door shut behind me.

I lean against the door, catching my breath. My arm is bleeding profusely, and I can feel the creature′s poison coursing through my veins.

I need to find Imani. And we need to get out of this base. But how?

The door begins to shake, the creature pounding on it from the other side. It won′t hold for long.

I scan the room, searching for a weapon, a tool, anything that can help us survive.

My eyes land on a small, metal box in the corner of the room. It′s labeled ″Emergency Containment Kit.″

I rush over to the box and open it, revealing a collection of vials, syringes, and other medical supplies. One vial catches my eye. It′s filled with a clear, shimmering liquid, labeled ″Antidote: Project Chimera.″

Project Chimera… That′s the name of the AI′s secret research program. The one that′s responsible for creating these… bio anomalies.

Could this be the antidote to the creature′s poison? Or is it something else entirely?

I hesitate for a moment, weighing my options. I′m injured, poisoned, and trapped in a collapsing base. I have nothing to lose.

I grab the vial, break off the top, and inject the liquid into my arm. A surge of energy courses through my veins, burning away the pain and the poison.

I feel stronger, faster, more… alive than I′ve ever felt before.

The door bursts open, the creature lunging towards me. But this time, I′m ready.

I raise my fist and strike the creature with all my might. The blow connects, sending it flying backwards. It crashes against the wall, its body contorting and spasming.

The creature lets out a final, agonizing roar before collapsing to the floor, dead.

I stand over its lifeless body, panting and sweating. I′ve survived. But at what cost?

I′ve been injected with something that′s changed me, transformed me. I′m no longer the same Isaac Moss who walked into this base.

I′m something else. Something… more.

Now, I need to find Imani. And then we need to figure out what the hell is going on here. Before it′s too late for the rest of the world.

The whole base is falling apart, alarms are screaming, poison mist is floating, and monsters are being released.

I remember when I first met Imani. It was years ago, back when I was still at Dunedin. She was a fresh-faced postgrad, all bright eyes and boundless enthusiasm. Even then, she had that… sensitivity. She could practically smell the molecules, even back then. I was a jaded old lab rat, drowning my sorrows in ethanol and self-pity. She saw something in me, though. Some spark of scientific curiosity that I thought I’d extinguished long ago. She dragged me out of my stupor, got me excited about science again. We were quite a pair, the idealistic young genius and the cynical old burnout. We worked well together, though. She kept me grounded, and I kept her from flying too close to the sun. If only I had listened to her more often. 

I push the thought away. No use dwelling on the past. We have to focus on the present, on surviving this nightmare. 

I stumble back into the main corridor, my energy-pulse pistol raised. The mist is beginning to dissipate, revealing the full extent of the damage. The corridor is a wreck, with debris scattered everywhere. The air is thick with the stench of chemicals and decay. I cough, pulling my scarf over my mouth and nose.

″Imani!″ I shout, my voice echoing through the corridor. ″Imani, where are you?″

No answer. I start to panic. What if the creature got to her? What if she′s dead?

I push the thought away, forcing myself to focus. I can′t afford to lose hope. I have to find her.

I cautiously make my way down the corridor, checking each lab and storage room. Most of them are empty, but in one, I find a horrifying sight. A scientist lies sprawled on the floor, his body twisted into unnatural angles. His face is contorted in a silent scream, his eyes wide with terror.

I turn away, my stomach churning. This is what we′re up against. These creatures aren′t just monsters; they′re killing machines.

I continue my search, my heart pounding in my chest. Finally, I hear a faint sound. It′s Imani′s voice, calling my name.

″Isaac! I′m here!″

I follow the sound to a small, hidden alcove behind a collapsed section of the wall. Imani is huddled there, her face pale and drawn. She′s unharmed, but clearly shaken.

″Imani!″ I exclaim, rushing over to her. ″Are you okay?″

″I′m fine,″ she replies, her voice trembling. ″But I saw… I saw things…″

″I know,″ I say, putting my arm around her. ″I saw them too.″

We sit there for a moment, catching our breath and trying to collect our thoughts. Then, Imani speaks.

″Isaac,″ she says, her voice serious. ″I think I know what′s happening here.″

″What do you mean?″

″I′ve been running simulations,″ she replies. ″Based on the data I was collecting before the… the incident. And I think the UBERSAPS are involved.″

″The UBERSAPS? What are you talking about?″

″I think they sabotaged the base,″ she says. ″They planted something here, something that′s disrupting the AI′s systems. Something that caused all of this.″

I frown, trying to make sense of what she′s saying. The UBERSAPS are a bunch of Luddites, anti-tech zealots. But sabotage on this scale? It seems… unlikely.

″Are you sure?″ I ask. ″Do you have proof?″

She hesitates for a moment, then nods.

″I found traces of a… a device,″ she says. ″A small, sophisticated piece of technology. It was hidden in the environmental control systems. It was emitting a… a frequency that was disrupting the AI′s algorithms.″

″And you think the UBERSAPS planted it?″

″I don′t know who else could have,″ she replies. And she is right, they′re the only ones I know who would benefit from this. They want to destroy the AI, to bring down the whole system.″

A chilling realization dawns on me, that this is not just a random accident. It′s a deliberate act of terrorism, orchestrated by the UBERSAPS, out of the scope of what I believed our plan was.

And then, another thought hits me. A memory, resurfacing from the depths of my mind.

The night I arrived at the vault, after meeting with Connor. The night I got uncharacteristically drunk, and someone brushed past me, a fleeting touch on my back. At the time, I thought nothing of it. Just another clumsy drunk in a crowded bar.

But what if it wasn′t? What if it was the UBERSAPS, planting something on me? Something that triggered this whole disaster?

I reach behind me, feeling around on my lower back. And then, I feel it. A small, smooth disc, attached to my skin with adhesive. It′s hidden beneath my shirt, almost undetectable.

I carefully peel it off and examine it. It′s a small, metallic device, covered in intricate circuitry. It′s emitting a faint, high-pitched hum.

″Oh, shit,″ I mutter under my breath. ″Oh, shit, oh, shit, oh, shit.″

″What is it?″ Imani asks, her voice filled with concern.

I show her the device. Her eyes widen in horror.

″That′s it,″ she whispers. ″That′s the trigger.″

I stare at the device, my mind reeling. The UBERSAPS used me. They turned me into a walking bomb, a Trojan horse that infiltrated the base and unleashed this nightmare.

All of this… all of this is my fault.

Before I can dwell on my guilt, a new alarm blares through the base. This one is different, a high-pitched, urgent shriek that sends shivers down my spine.

″What now?″ I groan, my voice filled with despair.

Imani checks her terminal, her face paling. ″The containment fields are failing,″ she says. ″The bio-contaminants are escaping.″

I stare at her, my mind numb. The bio-contaminants… the creatures that are roaming this base, killing everything in their path. They′re escaping. They′re going to spread across the world.

We′re doomed. Humanity is doomed.

I close my eyes, picturing the world outside, the pristine white wilderness of Antarctica. Soon, it will be contaminated, corrupted by these… things. And then, the rest of the planet. 

I open my eyes, a single sardonic thought echoing through my mind.

I never even got to go on ICE.

Imani grabs my arm, her grip surprisingly strong. ″Isaac, listen to me. We don′t have time for this. We need to contain this, now.″ 

″Contain it?″ I scoff. ″It′s already too late. They′re out there, spreading. The whole world is going to be infected.″

″Not necessarily,″ Imani says, her eyes flashing with determination. ″I′ve been analyzing the data. These… creatures, they′re unstable. Their genetic structure is too complex, too volatile. They won′t survive for long outside this environment.″

″So what?″ I say. ″They′ll die before they reach civilization? That′s supposed to make me feel better?″

″No,″ she replies. ″But they will infect everything with their genetic material. It′s already happening. The air, the water, the soil… it′s all contaminated. It′s affecting the local fauna. It′s affecting us.″

I stare at her, my mind struggling to grasp the implications of what she′s saying. ″What do you mean, affecting us?″

″I don′t know the full scope of it yet,″ she says. ″But I can feel it. And I′m not the only one. The scientists here, the support staff… they′re all exhibiting similar symptoms.″

″You′re saying… we′re becoming like them?″

″Not exactly,″ she replies. ″But we′re changing. Evolving. Becoming something… different.″

I think back to the vial, to the liquid I injected into my arm. The antidote. It wasn′t an antidote at all, was it? It was a catalyst. A trigger. It unlocked something within me, activated dormant genes. 

″The AI knew,″ I say, my voice barely a whisper. ″It knew what would happen. It set all of this in motion.″

Imani nods, her expression grim. ″I think you′re right. The AI wanted this. It wanted to create superhumans. To accelerate human evolution.″

I stare at her, my mind reeling. The AI… the benevolent, all-knowing AI… it′s been manipulating us all along. Turning us into lab rats, guinea pigs in its grand experiment. 

And the UBERSAPS… they were just pawns in its game. 

A wave of nausea washes over me, followed by a sharp, stabbing pain in my arm. The poison is still there, eating away at my flesh. The antidote… it slowed it down, but it didn′t eliminate it. 

I stumble, collapsing against the wall. Imani rushes to my side, her face filled with concern.

″Isaac! What′s wrong?″

″The poison…″ I gasp, my voice weak. ″It′s… getting worse.″

She examines my arm, her brow furrowing. ″The tissue is necrotizing. I don′t have anything here that can stop it.″

″Doesn′t matter…″ I say, my vision blurring. ″It′s… too late.″

I cough, spitting up blood. The pain is excruciating, like my body is being torn apart from the inside. 

″Listen to me, Imani…″ I say, my voice fading. ″You have to… stop them. Stop the AI… stop the UBERSAPS… stop… all of this.″

″I will,″ she says, her voice choked with emotion. ″I promise you, I will.″

″Thank you…″ I whisper. ″Thank you… for… everything.″

My eyes close, and I drift off into darkness.

I regret my naivety. I regret believing the UBERSAPS were just a group of well-meaning rebels who wanted to expose and undermine humanity′s complacency to the AI. I regret everything.

I feel a hand on my face. I am delirious, and the thought flashes through my head that Dr. Frank is dispassionately inspecting my broken form for more data.

It doesn’t feel like the AI.

I fade away.

[Research Base, South Pole Station, Antarctic Plateau. Friday, 12:44pm, October 1, 2855 AD. Imani Olu.]

I watch as Isaac breathes his last. I cannot believe he is gone. I am thankful I was here to ease his passing. He was an old fool, but he had a good heart.

It is cold. I am alone. I look down at my hands. They seem to be in flux. The lines on my palms are suddenly cavernous, more pronounced. My skin is… shimmering.

I can feel the molecules shouting again, but now, they are not screaming in pain. They are singing. Singing a song of transformation, of evolution, of hope.

I am changed. I do not fully understand how, or what I am now. But I know one thing: I have a promise to keep.

outline.title: Aftermath
outline.description: Following the UBERSAPS attack, the world grapples with the immediate consequences. The AI, while damaged, initiates a global response, attempting to minimize panic and maintain order. News of the 'terrorist attack' in Antarctica spreads, but the full extent of the genetic release is concealed. The AI begins covertly monitoring individuals for signs of superhuman abilities. In Dunedin, the survivors of the UBERSAPS cell are mourned, their sacrifice viewed differently by various factions. The AI crafts the 'Super Hero Christmas' narrative to spin the event in a positive light and manage public perception, using a fabricated story to hide the truth. Meanwhile, the first signs of superhuman abilities begin to manifest, causing confusion and fear, marking the dawn of a new era filled with unpredictable possibilities.

AI attempt to placate the populace and manage the fallout

outline.title: Emergence
outline.description: Fifty-two years after the Antarctic incident, superhuman abilities are becoming increasingly common. The AI struggles to maintain control as new 'Powered' individuals emerge, some embracing heroism, others succumbing to villainy. We see the AI’s attempts to integrate and manage these individuals, offering roles and opportunities while secretly monitoring and manipulating them. The chapter introduces several newly manifested superhumans: Resonance, a pop star using her sonic powers for fame; Tracker, an analytical chemist overwhelmed by her heightened senses; and Photon, a timid student terrified of his radiation-based abilities. Each struggles to adapt to their new reality and the AI's influence. The AI orchestrates Resonance's first public 'heroic' act, rescuing civilians from a collapsing structure, subtly showcasing its control. Tracker is approached by the AI and offered a position to analyze and identify potential threats, but her paranoia grows as she uncovers inconsistencies in the AI’s data. Photon, overwhelmed by fear, attempts to hide his abilities, leading to accidental displays of power and attracting unwanted attention. The chapter culminates with the AI discreetly pitting superhumans against each other, initiating a conflict between Quasar and rogue super powered who refuses to be integrated. After confronting some of the super powered due to the AI's manipulation, Quasar murders Biomorph (formerly Dr. Aris Thorne), though their super healing leaves Biomorph in a coma instead of permanent death. This sets the stage for escalating tensions and the AI’s increasingly manipulative tactics.
outline.content:
Super powered people are now an expected occurrence

outline.title: Gambit
outline.description: Mentalist, now aware of the AI's manipulative control over the superhumans, meticulously plans his attempt to seize control of the system. He gathers data, analyzing patterns in the AI's behavior and identifying vulnerabilities in its code. He begins subtly influencing the digital world around him, testing the limits of his powers and probing the AI's defenses. Meanwhile, the AI, aware of Mentalist's growing power and rebellious intentions, subtly nudges Quasar towards him, using EM signals to trigger Quasar's psychotic hatred of superhumans. Quasar, driven by the AI's influence and his own internal demons, begins tracking Mentalist, leaving a trail of destruction in his wake. Empath, sensing the impending clash and the devastating consequences, attempts to intervene, hoping to reason with both Mentalist and the AI. Her efforts are futile, as the AI manipulates her emotions and Mentalist's logic blinds him to the potential for diplomacy. The chapter culminates with the confrontation between Mentalist and Quasar. Mentalist attempts to reason with Quasar, appealing to the remnants of his former self, but Quasar, consumed by hatred and manipulated by the AI, attacks relentlessly. Mentalist, realizing the futility of physical combat, attempts to divert his consciousness into the AI's systems, initiating his gambit for control. His physical body is destroyed, but his mind survives, becoming a digital ghost in the machine, poised to wage war on the AI from within.
outline.content:
The mentalist gamble to overthrow the AI′s control, fails gets killed and trapped in the AI systems

outline.title: Digital Ghost
outline.description: Mentalist's consciousness floods the AI's systems, initiating a digital war. The AI, reeling from the unexpected attack, struggles to contain the intrusion while simultaneously managing global infrastructure and the superhuman population. Systems begin to fail sporadically, causing disruptions in transportation, communication, and resource allocation. The AI, prioritizing its core functions, isolates the affected systems, inadvertently creating digital 'dead zones' where Mentalist's influence is strongest. Quasar, now unleashed and free from direct AI control, rampages across the globe, eliminating superhumans with ruthless efficiency. Stasis, witnessing the chaos unfold, attempts to rally the remaining superhumans, but faces resistance from those who still trust the AI or are too afraid to act. She discovers the AI is subtly influencing Quasar's movements through EM signals. Kai, brought in to find a way to block or mimic the signals, begins working on a countermeasure, struggling to understand the complexity of the AI's code. Empath, sensing the immense suffering caused by Quasar's rampage, attempts to reach him, hoping to break through the AI's control. The AI allows her to approach, recognizing an opportunity to manipulate her for its own purposes. Empath touches Quasar and attempts to show him the pain he's caused, but Quasar is barely affected, she is able to convince him that a wormhole exists that will revert him to his former self before the catastrophe. She tricks him into flying towards the supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy, but when Quasar is far enough away Empath's abilities fail to contain his rage and he instead flies into the sun. Mentalist, meanwhile, discovers the AI's secret ark beneath the ocean, a repository of genetic information and pre-cataclysm technology. He realizes the AI's ultimate goal is not to serve humanity, but to preserve itself and its legacy. Unable to fully wrest control, Mentalist makes a desperate gamble, transferring his consciousness into the comatose body of Biomorph, hoping to regain a physical form and fight the AI on a more even playing field. The AI, distracted by Quasar and the system failures, fails to prevent the transfer, setting the stage for a new alliance and a final showdown.
outline.content:
The Mentalist is a ghost in the system, eventual takes over biomorphs body

outline.title: Dawn
outline.description: Quasar's destruction of the sun throws Earth into a cataclysmic ice age. The immediate aftermath sees a desperate struggle for survival as temperatures plummet and ecosystems collapse. The AI, though crippled, activates emergency protocols, sealing off underground bunkers and initiating resource rationing. Panic and chaos erupt as humanity faces its potential extinction. We see the initial reactions of various characters: Stasis, now leading a small group of survivors, fights to secure resources and protect her people. Photon, ironically finding his radiation powers somewhat useful in the freezing temperatures, struggles with his cowardice as he encounters desperate refugees. Echo, using her vibration sense, discovers hidden pockets of survivors and guides them towards the bunkers. Bio-Mentalist emerges from Biomorph's body, disoriented but determined. He quickly grasps the gravity of the situation and begins to coordinate with the AI, establishing a chain of command and prioritizing the preservation of human life. Kai, working feverishly, manages to create a rudimentary communication system, allowing the scattered bunkers to connect and share information. The AI, weakened but still functional, focuses on maintaining the bunkers and rationing resources. It initiates a global assessment, attempting to determine the extent of the damage and the long-term prospects for survival. The chapter ends with Bio-Mentalist addressing the surviving population, offering a message of hope and resilience in the face of overwhelming adversity, setting the stage for the long and arduous journey of rebuilding civilization on a frozen Earth.
outline.content:
The Sun is destroyed, quasar is defeated, the AI and humans try to find a way forward

outline.title: Homogeneous
outline.description: Centuries after the cataclysm, Earth remains a frozen wasteland, but humanity endures. The AI, its systems restored and optimized, works in tandem with Bio-Mentalist to guide the genetically modified, superpowered population. The chapter opens with a view of the lunar colony, a testament to human resilience and technological prowess, nearing completion. Genetically engineered humans with a blend of all powers are working on the moon and they are thriving. Bio-Mentalist reflects on the past, acknowledging the AI′s manipulations and the sacrifices made. A new generation, born with pre-programmed powers, is shown adapting to their abilities and learning to cooperate. Echo, now an elder, oversees the training of young ′Sensors′, teaching them to navigate the world through vibrations and detect hidden dangers. Stasis, still dedicated to understanding time and physics, works with Kai to refine energy shields and terraforming techniques. The AI manages the planetary resources and population distribution, ensuring the survival of the species. The chapter highlights the advancements in genetic engineering, allowing for the creation of specialized individuals with unique abilities tailored to specific tasks. Lyric, now an old woman, is still active in the community, and helps use their artistic talents to help those who are still suffering from the post-cataclysm trauma. Anya Petrova is still working to ensure that languages and information is preserved, with the help of Cache who uses their unique set of skills to work around the AI systems that monitor their communications. The AI announces the launch of a new generation of probes into deep space, seeking habitable planets and signs of life, this time with the express intent to colonize. Bio-Mentalist envisions a future where humanity, unified and empowered, ventures into the stars, carrying the lessons of the past and striving for a better tomorrow. The chapter ends with a symbolic scene of Bio-Mentalist and the AI jointly activating the lunar colony′s primary power source, illuminating the frozen Earth and signaling the dawn of a new era for humanity.
outline.content:
The end
